"Occidental Petroleum's financial position has been strengthened through debt reduction, with $3 billion removed from its debt load as part of a $4.5 billion plan.

The company's debt has decreased by 60% from its peak.

OPEC and the International Energy Agency have lowered their global oil demand growth forecasts, citing weaker Chinese consumption this year.

The market is expected to have a "heavy surplus" of oil supplies in 2025, according to Macquarie Group.

Wells Fargo analysts project Brent Crude will average $70 per barrel next year.

Occidental's direct-air-capture (DAC) technology investments are seen as promising for its future growth.

Microsoft has agreed to buy 500,000 metric tons of carbon dioxide removal credits over six years for Occidental's DAC facility.

The U.S. Department of Energy has awarded $500 million to 1PointFive to support the development of its direct-air-capture hub in Texas, with a potential increase to $650 million if it develops an expanded regional carbon network.
